item.title: Markov chaining my PhD thesis
item.description: Matt Dray Thatâ€™s â€˜doctorâ€™ to you I wrote a PhD thesis in 2014 called Effects of multiple environmental stressors on litter chemical composition and decomposition while at Cardiff University. On graduation day, a stranger came up to me and, to paraphrase, said â€˜you doctors should be proud of what youâ€™ve achieved, youâ€™re doing a great serviceâ€™. I didnâ€™t have the heart to tell him that I wasnâ€™t a medical doctor.

item.title: Mail merge in 2018 with R
item.description: Matt Dray Two-thousand and late Clip art! Fax machines! CD-ROMs! Dial-up modems! The World Wide Web! Mail merge! These exotic terms give me flashbacks to computer class at the turn of the millennium. The last oneâ€“mail mergeâ€“was taught as a way to autocomplete template Word letters for made-up customers in an Access database. I no longer need to invoice â€˜Mr Sonic The-Hedgehogâ€™ for ordering â€˜25 chili dogsâ€™, but the general approach of generating the same template multiple times with different information is still pertinent.

item.title: Cloudy with a chance of pie
item.description: Matt Dray The pinnacle of visualisation Great news everyone: Iâ€™ve taken the best of two stellar data visualisations and smashed them together into something that can only be described as perfection. Let me set the scene. item.title: Pokeballs in Super Smash Bros
item.description: Matt Dray Smash! Super Smash Bros (SSB) is a beat â€™em up videogame series featuring characters from various Nintendo franchises and beyond. The series has featured on Nintendo 64 (Super Smash Bros, 1998), Gamecube (SSB Melee, 2001), Wii (SSB Brawl, 2008), Wii U and 3DS (SSB â€˜4â€™, 2014) and an upcoming title for the Switch console. The game is popular enough to have resulted in a series of organised tournaments1.

item.title: TWO DOGS IN TOILET ELDERLY LADY INVOLVED
item.description: Matt Dray TL;DR Animals get stuck in weird places. Oh, and the sf package in R can be used for coordinate reprojection prior to interactive mapping with leaflet. The problem I often work with data that has coordinates; usually a eastings and northings. I need to convert these to latitude and longitude for interactive mapping using the leaflet package in R.

item.title: R Trek: exploring stardates
item.description: Matt Dray Captainâ€™s log ğŸ“– Star date 71750.51. Our mission is to use R statistical software to extract star dates mentioned in the captainâ€™s log from the scripts of Star Trek: The Next Generation and observe their progression over the course of the showâ€™s seven seasons. There appears to be some mismatch in the frequency of digits after the decimal point â€“ could this indicate poor abillity to choose random numbers?
